author: Rijneveld, Marieke Lucas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The disturbing story of a family in a rural area in the Netherlands as narrated by Jas, a ten-year-old girl whose imagination is capable of the most uThe disturbing story of a family in a rural area in the Netherlands as narrated by Jas, a ten-year-old girl whose imagination is capable of the most unexpected descriptions, some of them beautifully poetic and others repulsively descriptive, and written in a style that I can only describe as forceful and impressive, since it feeds constantly with recurring themes that become leitmotivs throughout the novel, and act as a chain reaction, giving the story a sense of completeness, escalating in intensity from the first page to the last. Early in the story, Jas is worried her rabbit pet will be part of the Christmas dinner menu. Rabbits, toads, moles, chickens, fish, cows are all part of the imagery and related to a sense of sacrifice, where animals are part of what later on will turn to be a bizarre rite. As if they were to die in order to preserve the life of humans.I pictured the way Dad would use that hand to wring my rabbit’s neck, like the childproof top of a canister of nitrogen: there was only one right way to do it. I imagined Mum laying out my lifeless pet on the silver dish she used for Russian salad on Sundays after church. She’d display him on a bed of lamb’s lettuce and garnish him with gherkins, tomato chunks, grated carrot and a sprig of thyme. I looked at my hands, at their irregular lines. They were still too small to be used for anything other than holding stuff. They still fitted in my parents’ hands but Mum’s and Dad’s didn’t fit in mine. That was the difference between them and me – they could put theirs around a rabbit’s neck, or around a cheese that had just been flipped in its brine. Their hands were always searching for something and if you were no longer able to hold an animal or a person tenderly, it was better to let go and turn your attention to other useful things instead.And as she describes what she sees, she draws a line between “them and me”, that will develop into a conceptual set of fixed ideas in her mind. I didn’t understand why the rope was hanging in the attic and not in the shed with the screwdrivers and his collection of bolts. Maybe, I thought, Dad wanted us to watch; maybe it would happen if we sinned. I briefly pictured my rabbit hanging broken-necked from the rope in the attic And as if it were a matter of choice, at one point, she prays: I thought about being too small for so much, but that no one told you when you were big enough, how many centimetres on the door-post that was, and I asked God if He please couldn’t take my brother Matthies instead of my rabbit. ‘Amen'. Matthies dies and Jas regrets what she had hoped for. Guilt is at the core of the biblical references that abound in the story, since the family is very much attached to the religious dogma of a Christian community where the pastor (and God, of course) is the central figure. Now, I am not a religious person, and all those quotes from the Bible seemed to me excessive. Due to repetition or insistence, I finally realized that these references were a way to manifest creation and its flaws. In the nights that followed, I kept sneaking downstairs to check whether my brother was really dead. First I’d lie in my bed wiggling around or ‘making a candle’, as I called it, by throwing my legs up in the air and supporting my hips with my hands. In the mornings his death seemed obvious but as soon as it grew dark, I’d begin to have my doubts. What if we hadn’t looked hard enough and he woke up under the ground? Each time, I’d hope that God had changed his mind and hadn’t listened to me when I’d prayed for him to protect Dieuwertje.If I went downstairs now, I hoped, it wouldn’t be Matthies lying beneath the sheet but my rabbit. Of course I’d be sad, but it would be different from the beating veins in my forehead when I tried to hold my breath in bed to understand death, or when I made the candle for so long my blood ran to my head like candlewax. The juxtaposition of night and day as opposites is a dominant idea throughout the novel, as expressed in the title itself, and takes form in various ways, life and death, here and there, inside and outside, below and above. I gradually start looking down at our family from above, too, so it’s less noticeable how little we amount to without Matthies. The empty place at the table now only has a seat and a chair-back that my brother can no longer casually set his weight against, causing my dad to roar, ‘Four legs!’ No one’s allowed to sit on that chair either. I guess that’s in case he comes back one day. ‘If Jesus returns, it will be a day just like any other. Life will go on as usual. Just like when Noah built his ark, people will be busy working and eating, drinking and getting married. Matthies will be as entirely expected as He is, when he returns,’ Dad had said at the funeral. In the coffin, Matthies’s face looked like it was made of beeswax, so smooth and tight. The nurses had stuck tissue paper under his eyelids to keep them shut, while I’d have preferred them to be open so that we could look at each other one more time, so that I could be sure I didn’t forget the colour of his eyes, so that he wouldn’t forget me.Scatological images due to Jas' constipation lead to grotesque scenes that I’m sure have scandalized many readers. I’m lying on my side on the brown leather settee like a breech calf, looking back at my father. He’s wearing his blue skipper’s jersey, which means he’s relaxed and the cows have been nice to him today. I’m anything but relaxed. I haven’t been able to poo for days, which has made my belly hard and swollen under my coat, like the Bundt cake my mother sometimes lets rise under a striped tea-towel. The three kings were given Bundt cake on their way back from Bethlehem, and their turbans were used as a mould, which is why it is ring-shaped. I mustn’t let go of my poo before we find the star, though even sitting hurts. I can’t imagine travelling for hours.He says nothing, just unzips his skipper’s collar a little further. I see a chunk of bare chest. Using his thumbnail, he breaks off a chunk of the bar of green soap he’s holding. In panic, I run through the last few days in my head. Have I said a blush word without Lingo being on? Have I been mean to Hanna? Before I can think about it any further, Dad has shoved the chunk of soap deep into my bum hole with his index finger. I just manage to smother a scream in the cushion under my face. I sink my teeth into the fabric. I can see the pattern on the cover through my tears. Triangles. For the first time since Matthies’s death, I cry. I have only covered the first chapters of the novel in this brief , since my intention is not to reveal the plot itself but just point out what for me are the most important elements of Rijneveld’s style. An impressive use of imagery in what I can only describe as brave and intrepid narrative in a debut novel that will attract some readers and dissuade others. Not an easy book to rate. Four stars....more

review: Cada uno de nosotros imaginaba cómo abandonar a los amigos a través del suicidio. Y les reprochaba, sin jamás hablar de ello, el hecho de tener que peCada uno de nosotros imaginaba cómo abandonar a los amigos a través del suicidio. Y les reprochaba, sin jamás hablar de ello, el hecho de tener que pensar en ellos y de no haber llegado a tal extremo por su causa. De ese modo, cada uno de nosotros se tornaba vanidoso y tenía siempre a mano el silencio que culpaba a los demás por el hecho de que tanto él como ellos siguieran vivos. El esfuerzo de salvarnos residía en la paciencia. No podía acabársenos la paciencia, o si se nos acababa debíamos recuperarla de inmediato.Herta Müller ha descrito esta novela como autobiográfica y en su mente, está dedicada a los amigos, camaradas de esa época en Rumania durante la dictadura de Ceaușescu. El supuesto suicidio de Lola, con quien la protagonista comparte una habitación es el inicio de una amistad entre cinco jóvenes que buscan sobrevivir, creando entre ellos, a manera de protección, fuertes lazos afectivos. Pero como las piezas de un tablero, la suerte que le es reservada a cada uno, afecta en su centro al círculo que han formado. Vi la bestia de su corazón. Pendía encerrada en la bombilla. Estaba encorvada y cansada. Cerré la nevera de un golpe porque la bestia del corazón no era robada. Sólo podía ser la suya; era más fea que las entrañas de todos los animales del mundo.Con escritura fragmentada, que seguramente representa el estado del ser bajo la tiranía de la dictadura, donde la libertad es aniquilada por el miedo, la narrativa de Müller en momentos se turna compleja y difícil de seguir. Y es esta calidad de fractura la que da su singularidad a la narrativa, que en su estado más simple, abandona la rítmica tradicional para crear un nuevo lenguaje. Es ahí que radica en mi opinión la fuerza de La bestia del corazón. Todos vivían de los sueños de fuga. Querían cruzar el Danubio a nado hasta que el agua se tornara extranjera. Correr por el maíz hasta que la tierra se tornara extranjera. Se les notaba en los ojos: muy pronto se gastarán todo lo que tienen en comprar mapas a los agrimensores. Esperan días de niebla en el campo y el río para poder huir corriendo o nadando, para esquivar las balas y los perros de los vigilantes. Se les notaba en las manos: pronto construirán globos, pájaros frágiles de sábanas y árboles jóvenes. Esperan que el viento no deje de soplar para que puedan huir. Se les notaba en los labios: pronto cuchichearán con un guardavía y le darán todo lo que tengan. Subirán a los trenes de mercancías para marcharse.Una novela sobre el anhelo de libertad, la fuerza de las convicciones y el deseo de vivir. ____...more

review: "Creo que si alguien supiese la historia de mi vida la vería como una vida mal vivida, llena de secretos, traiciones, ocultamientos. Pero en esta hist"Creo que si alguien supiese la historia de mi vida la vería como una vida mal vivida, llena de secretos, traiciones, ocultamientos. Pero en esta historia en la que casi todo lo que hago lo hago mal, me prermito creer que hay una cosa, una sola cosa, que hago bien. O una cosa mala de la que por lo menos me preservo."La narradora es Ofelia Fernández, nacida en el seno de una familia de clase media alta en el barrio de Palermo en Buenos Aires en los años cincuenta. Su historia, plagada de todas las contradicciones y juicios de una época y contada con sinceridad desbordante, representa el sentir de un país envuelto en tormentas políticas que se manifiestan en interminables pláticas de sobremesa de una familia unida por lazos de una fuerza inusitada. De Eduardo Sacheri había leído "La noche de la Usina", que me pereció estupenda. "Lo mucho que te amé" no lo es menos. Con verdadera maestría, el autor logra dar voz a una mujer atrapada en la moral de una sociedad, que busca encontrar su propio camino, cueste lo que cueste. "Si ese domingo de noviembre de 1953 me hubiera quedado callada, o me hubiera horrorizado módicamente, la cosa no pasaba a mayores. Queda como un secreto entre ambos. Un muchacho confundido. Confundido y bocón, eso es todo."Y es marca de un buen escritor lograr mimetizar su voz, convertirse en ese personaje y dejar atrás al creador para dar vida a lo que llamamos el estilo literario. "Pero además de esa vida soy este secreto. Y en el centro de este secreto soy libre de ser la mujer que quiero ser, o que me sale ser. Y si el precio de serlo es que jamás nadie lo sepa, que sea. Que sea ese el precio. Que todo esto permanezca en el más absoluto silencio. Que nadie sepa, nunca, ni ahora mientras caminamos en esta procesión callada, ni dentro de muchos años cuando sea una viejita memoriosa, Manuel, querido mío, lo mucho que te amé."Y no aspirar a sera más de lo que es (sin darse vuelos de elevada hechura) una sencilla historia pero bien contada, es también marca de una gran novela....more

Une oeuvre c'était N'était'il pas remarquable que seuls les temps de l'écriture puissent ainsi faire déborder les frontières du lieu où il habitait ? Une oeuvre c'était quelque chose, pensait'il, où le matériau n'était presque rien et la disposition presque tout ; quelque chose qui au repos restait en mouvement, sans rien pour la faire tourner, où tous les éléments se maintenaient eux-mêmes en suspens ; qui était ouverte, accessible à chacun et inusable. Dans son rêve de jeunesse, la littérature avait été, pour l'écrivain, le plus libre de tous les pays et la seule issue possible à toutes les vilenies et à toutes les humiliations quotidiennes, la seule pour parvenir à une égalité digne.Et qui, de plus, pouvait prétendre être assez artiste pour affirmer en lui un espace intérieur au monde ? À ce front de questions cette réponse ; en m'étant mis à l'écart - il y a combien d'années de cela ? - et en me retirant pour écrire, j'ai reconnu ma défaite en tant qu'être social : je me suis exclu des autres à jamais. J'aurai beau venir m'asseoir ici, au milieu du peuple, fêté, étreint, initié à ses secrets - Je n'en ferai jamais partie....more

She confessed it only to David, wanting to know if he ever experienced t"This problem of hers had begun about four years ago, soon after Viv’s birth. She confessed it only to David, wanting to know if he ever experienced the same sensation, trying and failing to capture it in words: the minor disorientations that sometimes plagued her, the small errors of eyes and ears. The conviction that the rumble underfoot was due to an earthquake rather than a garbage truck. The conviction that there was something somehow off about a piece of litter found amid the fossils in the Pit at work. A brief flash or dizziness that, for a millisecond, caused reality to shimmer or waver or disintegrate slightly. In those instants, her best recourse was to steady her body against something solid—David, if he happened to be nearby, or a table, a tree, or the dirt wall of the Pit—until the world resettled into known patterns and she could once more move invincible, unshakable, through her day."The dictionary defines fiction as “literature in the form of prose, especially short stories and novels, that describes imaginary events and people.” It is through the imagination of the author that the door opens to another reality. In Helen Phillips latest novel The Need, the central figure is a mother of two that imagines the presence of someone else in her home, because of a psychological condition that could perhaps be DID.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissoci... At first revealed by footsteps she hears while in another room, then by objects that disappear and finally by a face to face encounter, it is in the early part of the novel that the “problem” is acknowledged and traced back to the birth of her daughter Viv. “She wondered if other mothers experienced it, this permanent state of mild panic, and worried that perhaps they didn’t, that perhaps there was something wrong with her. What a phenomenon it was to be with her children, to spend every moment so acutely aware of the abyss, the potential injury flickering within each second.”And therefore, we are in the imagination of the imagined, a truly interesting idea that dominates the whole of the novel, as if stating that there could be fiction in within fiction itself. As every good writer knows, characters tend to have a life of their own, and although their unique creations, at times they no longer commit to their creators’ commands. In other words, they free themselves and do as they please. And this seems to be what happens to the other Molly, that the author cleverly calls Moll. And so we have the duality of a character of a character, moving through the pages of a novel as in the hallways of a house. “…the woman moved aside only at the last second, seeming suddenly to notice the children, and half bowing to them, the slightest odd obsequious gesture, though perhaps Molly imagined it;”When I began reading it, I thought right away that this book (in its metaphysical conception) could very well be the kind that David Lynch would love to make a film out of. Because the pages are filled with little signals, just as in Mulholland Drive: a set of keys, a pair of jeans, a cup of tea, a bootle of Coke. And they are there to guide us through and keep our attention on every detail of the writing. Otherwise we, as readers, would feel completely lost. “It was then that she noticed, there inside on the coffee table, her keys, the ones she had used not an hour earlier to open her locker at work, that unmistakable beaded loop Viv had made at preschool. How had this woman possibly gotten ahold of her key chain? Enraged, she reached into her pocket. But her keys were there. The exact same keys.” Perhaps what Molly is experiencing is in the realm of astral projection: a soul or consciousness that is separated from the physical body. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astral_... There is a scene in Lost Highway that comes to mind. The main character (Bill Pullman) is drinking at the bar during a party and a man approaches him with a mysterious smile. “We’ve met before, haven’t we?” “I don’t think so”, replies Pullman and adds “where was it you think we’ve met?”, “At your house”, answers the man. “Are you sure?”, asks Pullman. “Of course. As a matter of fact I’m there right now”. And so he hands him his phone and tells him to dial his number and there he is, answering in Pullman’s house while being in front of him at the party. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qZowK...There are a number of possibilities of what really happens to Molly, which I leave to other readers to decipher. Each of us will have our own version, because after all, literature is a personal matter. Even though Molly and Mol are the same person, Phillips makes us see the little differences in them. As we go through the chapters, almost all of them short and concise, repetitive in what NEEDS to be repeated, since obsession is one of the main traces of Molly's character, we realize that time is affected by this need to go over and over a phrase, a moment, an instant. “Later, when she asked him what time it was, he said 6:23, and then when she asked him again seven hours after that, he said 6:24, and then when she asked him again three minutes after that, he said midnight.”A fresh and original novel about motherhood, otherness and the power of the mind, written in the form of short chapters that convey the message about the presence of the “other” in our lives. Not an easy subject to handle. However, Helen Phillips does it very well....more

author: Obioma, Chigozie*

review: He inhaled. It was hard for him to talk about this phenomenon because it often moved him. For it was one of the things that he cherished about the He inhaled. It was hard for him to talk about this phenomenon because it often moved him. For it was one of the things that he cherished about the domestic birds – their fragility, how they relied chiefly on him for their protection, sustenance, and everything. In this they were unlike the wild birds.‘It is true, Mommy, it is cry,’ he said.‘Really?’‘That is so, Mommy.’‘Oh, God, Nonso! No wonder! Because of the small one—’‘That is so.’‘That the hawk took?’‘That is so, Mommy.’‘That is very sad, Nonso,’ she said after a moment’s quiet. ‘But how did you know they were crying?’‘My father told me. He was always saying it is like a burial song for the one that has gone. He called it Egwu umu-obereihe . You understand? I don’t know umu-obere-ihe in English.’‘Little things,’ she said. ‘No, minorities.’The tragic story of a Nigerian farmer and his long journey of suffering, because of the woman he loves. Narrated by his 700 year old guardian spirit or chi (following Igbo cosmology) we learn from the very beginning that his host, Chinonso Solomon Olisa has done something wrong for which his spirit intercedes on his behalf: I stand before you here in the magnificent court of Bechukwu, in Eluigwe, the land of eternal, luminous light, where the perpetual song of the flute serenades the air. Like other guardian spirits, I have gone to uwa in many cycles of reincarnations, inhabiting a freshly created body each time. I stand here before you, as bold as a king’s tongue, to plead my host’s cause, knowing that you will hear my voice.I have seen it many times, the spirit affirms over and over as he tries to recount and explain the misfortunes that fall upon his host. A powerful novel narrated with great conviction by Chigozie Obioma. A chance encounter in a bridge, a woman in distress, social classes, education, the strong and the weak, conviction, love, sacrifice, tragedy, adversity, evil, repentance, injustice, hate, vengeance and the predictability of human behavior. The strength in the writing comes directly from personal experience. In an interview the author said that when he was in Cyprus he met a Nigerian man that had gone there to study and make money to then go back to Nigeria to the woman he loved. The book is a compendium of human nature, through destiny and chance and it opens the door to an unknown world of traditions and beliefs. And thus, the novel brings this new and fresh perspective and opens our eyes to a different reality. ‘Oh God! Nonso, they are! It is like a coordinated song, the kind they sing during burial ceremonies. Like a choir. And what they are singing is a song of sorrow. Just listen, Nonso.’ She stood silent for a moment, then she stepped back a bit and snapped her fingers. ‘It is true what your father said. It is an orchestra of minorities.’Some of the most beautiful moments happen when the lovers are together and in conversation. We realize that their worlds and upbringing are complete opposites BUT that does not stop them from building their own kingdom. He raised his head again and saw that her eyes were closed.‘Like even now. You see? Why? Because they are umu-obere-ihe , minorities. See what the powerful have done to us in this country. See what they have done to you. And weak things.’She took a deep breath, and he wanted to speak but did not know what to say. He could hear the sound of her breath even though it was a cool day and the air was stifling. And he could tell that what she was saying was coming from deep within her, as if she were drawing water from a dried-up well, bringing up dregs, scrap metal, dead ferns and whatever lay in its bed.‘See what the powerful have done to us, Nonso?’ she said again, stepping back as if to leave, and then turning to him again. ‘Why? Because you’re not rich like them. And isn’t it true?’In my view, some of the sections are a little too long and this made me wonder who the central figure in the novel really is. At moments, the pleading of the chi when he addresses the gods is repetitively long and looses force because of this. Nevertheless, the narrative is quite well constructed throught. I give it four stars. This is only Obioma's second novel and both have been shortlisted for the Booker Prize, an impressive accomplishment of the young and very promising Nigerian writer....more

review: As a 12-year-old boy in Tallahassee, Elwood Curtis’ most precious possession was the LP Martin Luther King at Zion Hill, a gift from his grandmother HAs a 12-year-old boy in Tallahassee, Elwood Curtis’ most precious possession was the LP Martin Luther King at Zion Hill, a gift from his grandmother Harriet. The reverend’s words not only gave him a language but filled his mind with notions that helped craft and develop his character: "We must believe in our souls that we are somebody, that we are significant, that we are worthful, and we must walk the streets of life every day with this sense of dignity and this sense of somebody-ness." They provided meaning to his life, during the tough years of Jim Crow laws. One had to fight the evil forces, stand up against injustice and above all, one had to have dignity and perseverance. The last two words could very well describe Colson Whitehead’s novel, about a kid whose life takes a wrong turn of bad luck and ends up growing up the hard way. And so, the story takes him to the Nickel Academy, a reform school where the boys were frequently abused. The beatings took place at the “ice cream factory” and some never made it out, their bodies illegally buried in the nearby fields. At Nickel, Elwood turned once more to Dr. King for consolation. He talked about the need to transform the descent into action: "It will enrich your spirit as nothing else can", said the reverend, with his deep and illuminating voice. "It will give you that rare sense of nobility that can only spring from love and selflessly helping your fellow man. Make a career of humanity. Make it a central part of your life." Little did he know what life had in store for him.The school was a mirror of the country. The administrative building was even known as The White House. Segregation inside was as ferocious as in the outside world, punishment as vicious and injustice as cruel. The author greatly succeeds in recreating this world in within, describing in detail everything his eye could catch and going deep inside the fears that haunted the boys. At one point, the story shifts in time and the chapters alternate between a present in New York City and a past at the academy. This literary resource turns to be quite effective and we realize right at the end (in the Epilogue), the reason for it. And so, by opting for a hypothetical time period, with the aim of creating an imaginary world, Whitehead builds his novel on what seem to be real facts that are transformed through his narrative, just as he did in The Underground Railroad. The spirit of Martin Luther King throughout the story serves not only as inspiration but as catharsis: honest words can purify and heal. Right at the end, in the Acknowledgments he describes the book as fiction, the characters are my own, he writes, and then explains that the novel is inspired by the story of the Dozier School for Boys, in Marianna, Florida. Once more, life and fiction cross paths.#BlackHistoryMonth__...more

review: The decisions a novelist makes when embarking in a new project are numerous, some having to do with the subject matter and others with the manner in wThe decisions a novelist makes when embarking in a new project are numerous, some having to do with the subject matter and others with the manner in which it will unfold and develop. The way the words are put together one after the other, that part of grammar we call syntax is of utmost importance, since the project itself will depend a great deal in the choice made. Lucy Ellmann, an American writer who has lived in Scotland since her teens, has had the bold determination of writing a one-thousand-page novel in one single sentence, interrupted in what can be called structural moments of the story, by the monologue and journey of a lioness and her cubs. The narrator is a housewife in Ohio, who runs a baking business, has four kids and is married to her second husband. The inner voice is in stream of consciousness, a writing technique of which there are various examples in literature. But Ellmann’s novel is unique, since what is remarkable here is the fact that the entire novel is composed this way. “Conventional narrative techniques and dutiful compression would not have suited this project”, the author has said. One just has to flip through the pages of the book (thick and heavy) to realize that it’s all made of one continuous sentence, line after line, with no paragraph divisions and no dots till the very end. The author explains that it is “an approximation of consciousness…it follows the woman’s turns of thought, her associations, dreams, regrets. It seems to me the most interesting thing in the world, to find out what someone -anyone- is really thinking. Sometimes the narrator tries to steer her thoughts in directions she prefers, or recoils from certain darker avenues of thought, but she can’t keep it up for long. The bad thoughts will creep in, the mean thoughts, sad thoughts, crazy thoughts. We are all helpless amid this constant onslaught of the mind. Even when we’re asleep, we’re still thinking. Sounds, flashbacks, snatches of song, sights, smells and other sensations all come into it.”Rhythm is a crucial part of narrative; the way sentences intertwine with each other; the connections between one word and its neighbors; the flow of it all. To achieve this, Lucy Ellmann uses the formula “the fact that”, that is repeated over and over, and that strangely, like it happens with mantras in Buddhist’s chants, seems to disappear from our consciousness. And then, as we magically enter the subconscious, the length of the book is not an issue anymore, since it all becomes a continuous flow. “In my book “the fact that” is a plaintive refrain, and a technique meant to generate suspense. The book is not a conglomeration of facts. This “litany” is a way of diving beneath the dead zone of facts to a more personal realm.” I give it, no doubt, five stars. In my opinion the novel is a masterpiece of craftmanship, and it certainly points the direction to where narrative will be heading in the years to come. Galley Beggar Press deserves a lot of credit, since it came to the rescue (Ellmann’s previous publishers refused to embark on the project), and BELIEVED passionately in it. Having read three of the six novels that make the shortlist for the Booker Prize (and having given five stars to the other two as well), I am not ready yet to make a serious prediction. Nevertheless, Ducks, Newburyport stands at this moment, as my very favorite to win the prize....more

title: El obsceno pájaro de la noche
author: Donoso, José
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Una de las grandes novelas de la narrativa del siglo XX; pilar que sostiene el gran milagro literario de América Latina, que se conoce como el BOOM poUna de las grandes novelas de la narrativa del siglo XX; pilar que sostiene el gran milagro literario de América Latina, que se conoce como el BOOM porque fue una explosión de genialidad creativa sin precedentes en nuestro continente. José Donoso brilla intensamente en esta historia que se sitúa más allá de la locura, inventando un estilo que lleva la grandeza en el ímpetu y la rítmica de un lenguaje de intensidad sorprendente. Un verdadero tour de force cuya fuerza nace justamente de cada linea que alimenta la siguiente, creando una cadena interminable que se sostiene con el peso de cada palabra, eslabón indispensable cuya relación con el todo es fundamental. Una obra maestra, narrada magistralmente por un mudo omnipresente, cuyo alcance sobrepasa las paredes de esa vieja y derruida casona donde ancianas transmutan entre sí, fantasmas que deambulan los pasillos interminables de la noche, dónde el obsceno pájaro reina implacable.___________...more

review: Charles Pontiac et Jean-François Pons sont tous deux épris de Nicole Fischer. Elle leur préfère un troisième larron et devient veuve avant même de metCharles Pontiac et Jean-François Pons sont tous deux épris de Nicole Fischer. Elle leur préfère un troisième larron et devient veuve avant même de mettre au monde une petite Justine blonde et rose. Les deux amoureux évincés et éplorés partent donc dans d'autres mondes. L'un ira en Malaisie, l'autre sous les ponts de Paris. C'est une lecture qu'il faut y faire lentement sous peine de passer à côté de certaines tournures. Au fil du roman, se défont sans cesse des situations que l’écrivain avait bien nouées pour nous, parce que son écriture est faite pour déboussoler le lecteur, qui se raccroche à ce qu’il peut pendant que l’auteur s’amuse à faire de jolies phrases.  Le récit est haché, il se ralentit et s'accélère. Les séquences se succèdent sur un rythme proche de celui du cinéma....more
